protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
description:
This is a protocol from: 

Suttle, C. A. and J. A. Fuhrman. 2010. Chapter 15: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy. Manual of Aquatic Viral Ecology. Waco, TX:American Society of Limnology and Oceanography. doi:10.4319/mave.2010.978-0-9845591-0-7

Please see the published manuscript for additional information.
warning: Nucleic acid stains, phenylenediamine dihydrochloride and aldehyde-based fixatives are toxic; great care should be taken to avoid inhalation or contact with skin.

groups.group_name: Suttle Laboratory of Marine Molecular Microbiology and Virology

sub_authors.author_name: Curtis A. Suttle and Jed A. Fuhrman
Curtis A. Suttle and Jed A. Fuhrman

authors: Curtis A. Suttle and Jed A. Fuhrman

authors_list.name: Curtis A. Suttle and Jed A. Fuhrman

guidelines:
Authors: Curtis A. Suttle1 and Jed A. Fuhrman2
1Departments of Earth & Ocean Sciences, Microbiology & Immunology, and Botany, University of British Columbia, Vancouver, BC, Canada
2Marine Environmental Biology Section, University of Southern California, Los Angeles CA, USA

MATERIALS

Equipment
•Epifluorescence microscope equipped with the following:
     •≥100 W Hg-vapor or 150 W xenon lamp (xenon lamps are richer in the blue spectrum and have longer lifetimes and lower lifetime cost)
     •100x fluorescence objective (phase contrast objectives typically reduce brightness)
     •blue excitation filter (wide bandpass preferred for maximum brightness, e.g., 450-480 or 460-500 nm; excitation peaks 497, 495, and 491 nm for SYBR Green 1, SYBR Gold, and Yo-Pro-1, respectively)
     •dichroic mirror (beam splitter), typically 500 or 510 nm
     •long-pass sharp cutoff filter (typically 515 nm; emission peaks 520, 537, and 509 nm for SYBR Green 1, SYBR Gold, and Yo-Pro-1, respectively; a long-pass filter allows maximum brightness)
     •ocular reticule divided into 100 grid squares
     •stage micrometer
•Filtration unit, to hold 25-mm-diameter filters
•Vacuum pump
•Vacuum flask
•Pipettes suitable for dispensing 1 μL to 2 mL
•Event counter
•Filter forceps
•Sonicating bath (sediment samples only)
•Squeeze bottle (or similar) containing 0.2-μm filtered MilliQ water that will be used to wet the underlay filter.

Reagents and solutions
•(SYBR only) SYBR Green or SYBR Gold nucleic-acid gel stain, 10,000x concentrate in anhydrous DMSO (Invitrogen)
•(Yo-Pro only) Yo-Pro-1, 1 mM stock solution in a 1:4 solution of dimethyl sulfoxide and water (Invitrogen)
•(SYBR only) Antifade solution: p-phenylenediamine dihydrochloride or 1,4-phenylenediamine dihydrochloride (se Sigma P-1519 and not P-6001 [Patel et al. 2007] and store in a tightly capped container away from light)
•Spectrophotometric-grade glycerol
•Phosphate-buffered saline (PBS): 0.05 M Na2HPO4, 0.85% NaCl (wt/vol), pH 7.5)
•(Sediment samples only) Pyrophosphate (10 mM)
•0.02-μm filter autoclaved MilliQ H2O
•Tris EDTA (TE) buffer, pH 8 (for acidic samples)
•(Yo-Pro only) Aqueous NaCl solution (0.3% wt/vol)
•(SYBR only) 25% EM-grade glutaraldehyde, kept at 4°C
•Ethanol
•DF- or FF-grade immersion oil (refractive index 1/4, 1.516; Olympus).

Cautions: Nucleic acid stains, phenylenediamine dihydrochloride and aldehyde-based fixatives are toxic; great care should be taken to avoid inhalation or contact with skin.

Disposable supplies
•Anodisc Al2O3 filters, 0.02-μm pore size, 25 mm diameter, with support ring (Whatman)
Note: At the time of writing, GE Healthcare, which recently purchased Whatman, is considering discontinuing production of the Anodisc membrane. Currently, there are no other membranes known that are suitable for EFM counts of virus particles. For polycarbonate filters, the background fluorescence is too high (even if stained black) and the porosity is too low to filter an adequate volume of water.
•Nitrocellulose membrane filters, 0.45-μm pore size, 25 mm diameter
•Precleaned glass microscope slides, 25 x 75 mm
•Glass coverslips (25 x 25 mm) of proper thickness (each microscope objective has an optimal coverslip thickness--the cover glass is part of the optics; for example, an Olympus infinity-corrected 100x UVPlanApo is imprinted "∞/0.17," which indicates a 0.17-mm-thick cover glass, also known in the US as #1 1/2)
•2.0 mL sterile polypropylene microcentrifuge tubes
•2.0 mL screw-cap cryovials
•10 μL, 200 μL, and 1 mL sterilized pipette tips
•Polypropylene centrifuge tubes (15 or 50 mL)
•Petri plates
•Kimwipes (Kimberly-Clark) or other lint-free paper wipes
•9-cm-diameter paper filters (Whatman #1)
•Additional supplies for long-term storage of samples for SYBR staining:
     •Liquid nitrogen
     •Nylon stockings




Fig. 1. Epifluorescence micrographs of natural water samples. Viruses are indicated by solid arrows and bacteria by broken arrows.
(A), Yo-Pro 1–stained slide of a water sample from the Arctic Ocean (courtesy of J. P. Payet).
(B), SYBR Green I–stained water sample from the coastal waters of Southern California. The large object in the center is a pennate diatom.
(C) SYBR Gold–stained sample of a water sample from the Chesapeake Bay (courtesy of F. Chen and K. Wang). The slides emphasize the differences that occur between samples and different staining protocols.

source_data.description: For Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy protocol.
source_data.warning:
Reagents must be made in freshly prepared deionized 0.02-µm filtered water to prevent virus particles being introduced into the samples and causing high blanks.

Stains should always be handled in low light to prevent photodegradation. Because the stains are sensitive to repeated freezing and thawing, the stains should be aliquoted as stock solutions in small volumes.

components.data: For SYBR stains, make a secondary stock by diluting the concentrated dye supplied by the manufacturer 10-fold with 0.02-µm filtered deionized water (dH<sub>2</sub>O) and dispense into polypropylene screw-cap microcentrifuge tubes.

components.data: Each filter requires 2 µL SYBR stain; hence, 40 µL dispensed into each tube provides enough stain for 20 filters.

components.data: Prepare a solution of 50% glycerol and 50% PBS. The solution should be shaken or vortexed to ensure complete mixing, 0.02 µm filtered, and stored as a liquid at –20°C.

components.data: Prepare a 10% stock solution of the antifade reagent by diluting 1 g phenylenediamine (PDA) in 10 mL of 0.02-µm filtered autoclaved dH<sub>2</sub>O.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 8 of Preparation of reagents
source_data.protocol_name: Preparation of reagents
source_data.protocol_name_html: Preparation of reagents
source_data.annotation: The frozen reagent should be white; if it has a brownish tint it should not be used. It is possible to use other antifade reagents such as 0.5% (wt/vol) ascorbic acid in 50% (vol/vol) glycerol/PBS or SlowFade (Invitrogen), but they may provide less protection against fading (Noble and Fuhrman 1998). In contrast, DABCO (1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane) in TE/glycerol is reported to be a superior antifade to PDA (Ortmann, pers. comm.).

It is possible to use other antifade reagents such as 0.5% (wt/vol) ascorbic acid in 50% (vol/vol) glycerol/PBS or SlowFade (Invitrogen), but they may provide less protection against fading (Noble and Fuhrman 1998). In contrast, DABCO (1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane) in TE/glycerol is reported to be a superior antifade to PDA (Ortmann, pers. comm.).

In contrast, DABCO (1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane) in TE/glycerol is reported to be a superior antifade to PDA (Ortmann, pers. comm.).

source_data.description: For Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy protocol.

groups.group_name: Suttle Laboratory of Marine Molecular Microbiology and Virology

source_data.authors: Curtis A. Suttle and Jed A. Fuhrman

authors_list.name: Curtis A. Suttle and Jed A. Fuhrman

source_data.guidelines:
Preservation of samples (SYBR only): If slides cannot be made in the field on freshly collected samples, preservation will be necessary. Many earlier estimates of viral abundance have been made on preserved samples; however, several studies have shown rapid and significant decay of viral particles in aldehyde-fixed samples (Brussaard 2004; Danovaro et al. 2001; Wen et al. 2004), although there is evidence that the decay is lessened when larger-volume samples are preserved (Patel et al. 2007). Samples preserved in the field should be flash-frozen in liquid nitrogen. Even freezing with dry ice (frozen CO2) or immediately freezing in a –87°C freezer is not adequate for preservation, and to our knowledge, freezing in a dry ice/ethanol slurry (–78°C) has not been tested. Samples to be preserved should be fixed in 0.5% (final concentration) EM-grade glutaraldehyde and flash-frozen in liquid N2. For relatively productive samples with virus abundances ≥106 mL–1, add 30 µL of 25% EM-grade glutaraldehyde into prelabeled 2-mL cryovials, add 1470 µL of the sample to be counted, and mix. These volumes can be halved for samples with virus abundances ≥107 mL–1 and increased to 4 mL in 5-mL cryovials for very oligotrophic samples. Allow the samples to stand for at least 15 min but no longer than 30 min, and then freeze immediately in liquid N2. To facilitate easy retrieval, vials can be placed in women’s nylon stockings before freezing. (We find black sheer ones the most aesthetically pleasing.) Once frozen, the vials can be transferred to –80°C for long-term storage, until the slides can be prepared. For counting, the frozen samples are thawed in a 37°C water bath and immediately stained with SYBR Green I or SYBR Gold, as outlined.

In the field, if it is impossible to make slides or preserve in liquid N, then it probably is best to collect the samples in as large volumes as is practical and maintain them under in situ conditions for as short a time as is possible until slides can be made.

components.data: Collect the samples in sterile containers that are rinsed three times with the sample water.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Collect the samples in sterile containers that are rinsed three times with the sample water.

components.data: The range of viral abundances suitable for enumeration is ~10<sup>5</sup> to 10<sup>7</sup> mL<sup>–1</sup>; hence, dilution may be necessary for very productive natural samples or cultures.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The range of viral abundances suitable for enumeration is ~10<sup>5</sup> to 10<sup>7</sup> mL<sup>–1</sup>; hence, dilution may be necessary for very productive natural samples or cultures.

components.data: If necessary, dilute the sample with 0.02-µm filtered water, ideally prepared from the same or very similar water from which the sample was obtained.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: If necessary, dilute the sample with 0.02-µm filtered water, ideally prepared from the same or very similar water from which the sample was obtained.

components.data: Undisturbed sediment samples should be collected with a piston corer.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Undisturbed sediment samples should be collected with a piston corer.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 4 of Sample collection and preparation
source_data.protocol_name: Sample collection and preparation
source_data.protocol_name_html: Sample collection and preparation
source_data.annotation: The sediment–water interface can be sampled with a wide-bore serological pipette to minimize disruption to the sediment surface.
source_data.thread_text: The sediment–water interface can be sampled with a wide-bore serological pipette to minimize disruption to the sediment surface.
source_data.body: The sediment–water interface can be sampled with a wide-bore serological pipette to minimize disruption to the sediment surface.

components.data: Samples from deeper within the core can be obtained by carefully pushing the core up from the bottom of the core barrel and slicing the sediment at the desired depth.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Samples from deeper within the core can be obtained by carefully pushing the core up from the bottom of the core barrel and slicing the sediment at the desired depth.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 5 of Sample collection and preparation
source_data.protocol_name: Sample collection and preparation
source_data.protocol_name_html: Sample collection and preparation
source_data.annotation: The sediment should be sampled from the center of the core, leaving a well-defined area of sediment around the periphery to ensure the sample is not contaminated with sediment smeared along the side of the core barrel.
source_data.thread_text: The sediment should be sampled from the center of the core, leaving a well-defined area of sediment around the periphery to ensure the sample is not contaminated with sediment smeared along the side of the core barrel.
source_data.body: The sediment should be sampled from the center of the core, leaving a well-defined area of sediment around the periphery to ensure the sample is not contaminated with sediment smeared along the side of the core barrel.

components.data: Remove a 0.5-cm<sup>3</sup> subsample of sediment from the center of the core slice and transfer it into 4 mL of 0.02-µm filtered seawater and 1.0 mL pyrophosphate (10 mM final concentration).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove a 0.5-cm<sup>3</sup> subsample of sediment from the center of the core slice and transfer it into 4 mL of 0.02-µm filtered seawater and 1.0 mL pyrophosphate (10 mM final concentration).
Sonicate the mixture for 3 min.

source_data.annotation: Potassium citrate has been reported to be superior to sodium pyrophosphate for extracting phage from soils (Williamson et al. 2003) and may be an alternative for aquatic sediments, as well.

components.data: (Yo-Pro only) Place a 9-cm-diameter filter paper soaked with 3 mL aqueous NaCl solution (0.3% wt/vol) in the lid of the Petri plates to prevent evaporation of the stain.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: (Yo-Pro only) Place a 9-cm-diameter filter paper soaked with 3 mL aqueous NaCl solution (0.3% wt/vol) in the lid of the Petri plates to prevent evaporation of the stain.

components.data: Connect a filtration unit for 25-mm filters to a vacuum source, ensuring the vacuum is ≤13 kPa.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Connect a filtration unit for 25-mm filters to a vacuum source, ensuring the vacuum is ≤13 kPa.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 13 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: A stronger vacuum will likely crack the filter.
source_data.thread_text: A stronger vacuum will likely crack the filter.
source_data.body: A stronger vacuum will likely crack the filter.

components.data: Place a 0.45-µm nitrocellulose backing filter on each filter support, and overlay it with a thin layer of dH<sub>2</sub>O.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place a 0.45-µm nitrocellulose backing filter on each filter support, and overlay it with a thin layer of dH<sub>2</sub>O.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 14 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: If the filter does not wet evenly (if there are areas or spots that remain white), replace the filter with another one. Backing filters can be reused if they are smooth, are wet evenly with water, and have no holes.
source_data.thread_text: If the filter does not wet evenly (if there are areas or spots that remain white), replace the filter with another one. Backing filters can be reused if they are smooth, are wet evenly with water, and have no holes.
source_data.body: If the filter does not wet evenly (if there are areas or spots that remain white), replace the filter with another one. Backing filters can be reused if they are smooth, are wet evenly with water, and have no holes.

components.data: Carefully pick up a 0.02-µm Anodisc filter by its plastic ring and lay it over the wet backing filter, with the plastic ring facing upward.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Carefully pick up a 0.02-µm Anodisc filter by its plastic ring and lay it over the wet backing filter, with the plastic ring facing upward.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 15 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: The Anodiscs are ceramic and break easily; make sure it is not cracked and that air is not trapped between the filters. If necessary, pull excess water through the filters using the vacuum, but make sure the filters remain wet.
source_data.thread_text: The Anodiscs are ceramic and break easily; make sure it is not cracked and that air is not trapped between the filters. If necessary, pull excess water through the filters using the vacuum, but make sure the filters remain wet.
source_data.body: The Anodiscs are ceramic and break easily; make sure it is not cracked and that air is not trapped between the filters. If necessary, pull excess water through the filters using the vacuum, but make sure the filters remain wet.

components.data: (SYBR only) If the sample has been preserved and frozen as described, thaw it in a 37°C water bath.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: (SYBR only) If the sample has been preserved and frozen as described, thaw it in a 37°C water bath.

components.data: (SYBR only) For a sample that has just been collected, fix it with 0.5% glutaraldehyde for 15–30 min at 4°C before preparing slides.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: (SYBR only) For a sample that has just been collected, fix it with 0.5% glutaraldehyde for 15–30 min at 4°C before preparing slides.

components.data: (SYBR only) In addition, prepare duplicate control samples by fixing 1 mL of the 0.02-µm filtered water that was used to dilute the SYBR stain.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: (SYBR only) In addition, prepare duplicate control samples by fixing 1 mL of the 0.02-µm filtered water that was used to dilute the SYBR stain.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 18 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: For some samples, fixation may improve the fluorescence of the particles and make counting easier. Also, some virus particles are prone to breakage if not fixed (Chan, pers. comm.).
source_data.thread_text: For some samples, fixation may improve the fluorescence of the particles and make counting easier. Also, some virus particles are prone to breakage if not fixed (Chan, pers. comm.).
source_data.body: For some samples, fixation may improve the fluorescence of the particles and make counting easier. Also, some virus particles are prone to breakage if not fixed (Chan, pers. comm.).

components.data: (Yo-Pro only) Because divalent cations interfere with the binding of the stain, seawater samples should be diluted to <7 psu with 0.02-µm filtered dH<sub>2</sub>O before filtration.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: (Yo-Pro only) Because divalent cations interfere with the binding of the stain, seawater samples should be diluted to <7 psu with 0.02-µm filtered dH<sub>2</sub>O before filtration.

components.data: It is a good idea to make test slides (including a control with no sample added) to be sure an appropriate volume is filtered, that the procedure is working, and that the filters and reagents do not have viruses on or in them (some batches of Anodiscs have been covered with bacteria and viruses).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: It is a good idea to make test slides (including a control with no sample added) to be sure an appropriate volume is filtered, that the procedure is working, and that the filters and reagents do not have viruses on or in them (some batches of Anodiscs have been covered with bacteria and viruses).

components.data: For most lake and coastal seawater samples, which have viral abundances of ~10<sup>7</sup> mL<sup>–1</sup>, 0.8–1.0 mL sample is added to the surface of the Anodisc filter while the vacuum is off.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: For most lake and coastal seawater samples, which have viral abundances of ~10<sup>7</sup> mL<sup>–1</sup>, 0.8–1.0 mL sample is added to the surface of the Anodisc filter while the vacuum is off.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 21 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: A filtration tower is not needed, as surface tension will hold the water on the surface of the filter.
source_data.thread_text: A filtration tower is not needed, as surface tension will hold the water on the surface of the filter.
source_data.body: A filtration tower is not needed, as surface tension will hold the water on the surface of the filter.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 21 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: Make sure the entire volume is within the plastic ring, or the sample will be pulled under the edge of the filter.
source_data.thread_text: Make sure the entire volume is within the plastic ring, or the sample will be pulled under the edge of the filter.
source_data.body: Make sure the entire volume is within the plastic ring, or the sample will be pulled under the edge of the filter.

components.data: Turn on the vacuum and suck the sample through the filter.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Turn on the vacuum and suck the sample through the filter.

components.data: For oligotrophic or very deep ocean samples, it may be necessary to filter 4 mL or more.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: For oligotrophic or very deep ocean samples, it may be necessary to filter 4 mL or more.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 23 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: If the volume to be filtered is slightly greater than 1 mL, the additional volume can be added while the sample is filtering, being careful to ensure the entire filter surface is continuously covered with liquid during filtration.
source_data.thread_text: If the volume to be filtered is slightly greater than 1 mL, the additional volume can be added while the sample is filtering, being careful to ensure the entire filter surface is continuously covered with liquid during filtration.
source_data.body: If the volume to be filtered is slightly greater than 1 mL, the additional volume can be added while the sample is filtering, being careful to ensure the entire filter surface is continuously covered with liquid during filtration.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 23 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: For larger volumes, a sterile filtration tower can be used; if the inside diameter of the tower is less than the filter diameter inside the plastic ring, it must be taken into consideration when calculating viral abundance.
source_data.thread_text: For larger volumes, a sterile filtration tower can be used; if the inside diameter of the tower is less than the filter diameter inside the plastic ring, it must be taken into consideration when calculating viral abundance.
source_data.body: For larger volumes, a sterile filtration tower can be used; if the inside diameter of the tower is less than the filter diameter inside the plastic ring, it must be taken into consideration when calculating viral abundance.

components.data: Filter towers must be cleaned between samples. Rinse the towers with 0.02-µm filtered dH<sub>2</sub>O followed by ethanol. Dry with lint-free paper (e.g., Kimwipe).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Filter towers must be cleaned between samples. Rinse the towers with 0.02-µm filtered dH<sub>2</sub>O followed by ethanol. Dry with lint-free paper (e.g., Kimwipe).

components.data: Once the sample is filtered, remove the Anodisc with the vacuum still on.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Once the sample is filtered, remove the Anodisc with the vacuum still on.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 25 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: There should not be any liquid on the surface of the filter. Touch only the plastic ring, so as not to crack the membrane. To assist in lifting the filter, a 10-µL pipette tip can be cut at a slight angle and slid under the filter edge. It also helps to place the Anodisc filter about a millimeter off center on the 0.45 underfilter, to provide an edge you can grasp with forceps.
source_data.thread_text: There should not be any liquid on the surface of the filter. Touch only the plastic ring, so as not to crack the membrane. To assist in lifting the filter, a 10-µL pipette tip can be cut at a slight angle and slid under the filter edge. It also helps to place the Anodisc filter about a millimeter off center on the 0.45 underfilter, to provide an edge you can grasp with forceps.
source_data.body: There should not be any liquid on the surface of the filter. Touch only the plastic ring, so as not to crack the membrane. To assist in lifting the filter, a 10-µL pipette tip can be cut at a slight angle and slid under the filter edge. It also helps to place the Anodisc filter about a millimeter off center on the 0.45 underfilter, to provide an edge you can grasp with forceps.

components.data: Allow the filter to air-dry (typically a minute or less), until the surface is visibly dry.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Allow the filter to air-dry (typically a minute or less), until the surface is visibly dry.

components.data: Place the Anodisc, sample side up, on a drop of stain in the Petri dish.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place the Anodisc, sample side up, on a drop of stain in the Petri dish.

components.data: (SYBR only) Allow the filter to stain for 15 min in the dark.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: (SYBR only) Allow the filter to stain for 15 min in the dark.

components.data: (Yo-Pro only) Allow the filter to stain for 48 h in the dark, at room temperature.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: (Yo-Pro only) Allow the filter to stain for 48 h in the dark, at room temperature.

components.data: Add a drop of dH<sub>2</sub>O on the backing filter, lay the stained Anodisc on top, and use the vacuum to remove any remaining fluid.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add a drop of dH<sub>2</sub>O on the backing filter, lay the stained Anodisc on top, and use the vacuum to remove any remaining fluid.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 30 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: Do not use the filter if there is visible water on top of the Anodisc when it is done staining, as it is likely cracked.
source_data.thread_text: Do not use the filter if there is visible water on top of the Anodisc when it is done staining, as it is likely cracked.
source_data.body: Do not use the filter if there is visible water on top of the Anodisc when it is done staining, as it is likely cracked.

components.data: (Yo-Pro samples and samples with high background fluorescence) Some samples (e.g., sediments, vent fluid, and humic waters) may require the filters to be rinsed to reduce background fluorescence. If so, while the vacuum is still on and the filter is damp, rinse the filter twice with 1 mL of 0.02-µm filtered dH<sub>2</sub>O.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: (Yo-Pro samples and samples with high background fluorescence) Some samples (e.g., sediments, vent fluid, and humic waters) may require the filters to be rinsed to reduce background fluorescence. If so, while the vacuum is still on and the filter is damp, rinse the filter twice with 1 mL of 0.02-µm filtered dH<sub>2</sub>O.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 31 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: For some samples, such as those with high humic content, or from vent environments, samples can be rinsed with TE buffer to reduce background fluorescence (Chan and Winget, pers. comm.).
source_data.thread_text: For some samples, such as those with high humic content, or from vent environments, samples can be rinsed with TE buffer to reduce background fluorescence (Chan and Winget, pers. comm.).
source_data.body: For some samples, such as those with high humic content, or from vent environments, samples can be rinsed with TE buffer to reduce background fluorescence (Chan and Winget, pers. comm.).

components.data: Remove the Anodisc while the vacuum is on.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove the Anodisc while the vacuum is on.

components.data: Place the Anodisc, sample-side up, on a 9-cm filter paper or Kimwipe in the dark, and allow the filter to dry until it appears opaque.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place the Anodisc, sample-side up, on a 9-cm filter paper or Kimwipe in the dark, and allow the filter to dry until it appears opaque.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 33 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: The filter paper can be placed inside the lid of a Petri plate, and a foil-lined Petri plate bottom can be used as a lid. It usually takes about 5 min for the filter to dry, but it can be longer when humidity is high. The process can be accelerated by laying the filter on a glass slide that is heated to 35–37°C on a heating block, often very helpful when humidity is high.
source_data.thread_text: The filter paper can be placed inside the lid of a Petri plate, and a foil-lined Petri plate bottom can be used as a lid. It usually takes about 5 min for the filter to dry, but it can be longer when humidity is high. The process can be accelerated by laying the filter on a glass slide that is heated to 35–37°C on a heating block, often very helpful when humidity is high.
source_data.body: The filter paper can be placed inside the lid of a Petri plate, and a foil-lined Petri plate bottom can be used as a lid. It usually takes about 5 min for the filter to dry, but it can be longer when humidity is high. The process can be accelerated by laying the filter on a glass slide that is heated to 35–37°C on a heating block, often very helpful when humidity is high.

components.data: (SYBR only) Place 12–15 µL antifade solution on a labeled glass slide and lay the dry Anodisc on top.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: (SYBR only) Place 12–15 µL antifade solution on a labeled glass slide and lay the dry Anodisc on top.

components.data: (SYBR only) Add ~20 µL antifade on top of the Anodisc and cover with a coverslip.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: (SYBR only) Add ~20 µL antifade on top of the Anodisc and cover with a coverslip.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 35 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: If the slides are to be frozen, add a little more antifade to compensate for sublimation.
source_data.thread_text: If the slides are to be frozen, add a little more antifade to compensate for sublimation.
source_data.body: If the slides are to be frozen, add a little more antifade to compensate for sublimation.

components.data: (Yo-Pro only) Place 12–15 µL spectrophotometric-grade glycerol on a labeled glass slide and lay the dry Anodisc on top.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: (Yo-Pro only) Place 12–15 µL spectrophotometric-grade glycerol on a labeled glass slide and lay the dry Anodisc on top.

components.data: (Yo-Pro only) Add ~20 µL glycerol on top of the Anodisc and cover with a coverslip.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: (Yo-Pro only) Add ~20 µL glycerol on top of the Anodisc and cover with a coverslip.

components.data: Remove any air bubbles that are trapped under the coverslip by gently pressing on the surface.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove any air bubbles that are trapped under the coverslip by gently pressing on the surface.

components.data: The slides can be counted immediately or stored frozen at –20°C for at least 4 months with no decrease in estimates of viral abundance.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The slides can be counted immediately or stored frozen at –20°C for at least 4 months with no decrease in estimates of viral abundance.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 39 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: Slides can be individually wrapped in a Kimwipe and placed in small batches in foil packets before freezing. This allows a few slides to be thawed at a time. Once thawed, the slides should be counted immediately.
source_data.thread_text: Slides can be individually wrapped in a Kimwipe and placed in small batches in foil packets before freezing. This allows a few slides to be thawed at a time. Once thawed, the slides should be counted immediately.
source_data.body: Slides can be individually wrapped in a Kimwipe and placed in small batches in foil packets before freezing. This allows a few slides to be thawed at a time. Once thawed, the slides should be counted immediately.

components.data: Count the viruses at 1000× magnification using a 100× oilemersion objective.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Count the viruses at 1000× magnification using a 100× oilemersion objective.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 40 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: Make sure that the area of the filter covered by the 10 × 10 ocular reticule has been determined using a stage micrometer.
source_data.thread_text: Make sure that the area of the filter covered by the 10 × 10 ocular reticule has been determined using a stage micrometer.
source_data.body: Make sure that the area of the filter covered by the 10 × 10 ocular reticule has been determined using a stage micrometer.

components.data: Begin by checking the test filters to ensure that the reagents or filters were not contaminated and the filtered volumes were appropriate.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Begin by checking the test filters to ensure that the reagents or filters were not contaminated and the filtered volumes were appropriate.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 41 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: Viral and bacterial particles will appear green (SYBR Green and Yo-Pro) or yellow (SYBR Gold) when excited with blue light (see Fig. 1 in guidelines).
source_data.thread_text: Viral and bacterial particles will appear green (SYBR Green and Yo-Pro) or yellow (SYBR Gold) when excited with blue light (see Fig. 1 in guidelines).
source_data.body: Viral and bacterial particles will appear green (SYBR Green and Yo-Pro) or yellow (SYBR Gold) when excited with blue light (see Fig. 1 in guidelines).

components.data: Check each slide before counting to make sure that the filter is evenly stained and that the viruses are on a single plane of focus and not suspended in the mounting medium and are evenly distributed across the filter.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Check each slide before counting to make sure that the filter is evenly stained and that the viruses are on a single plane of focus and not suspended in the mounting medium and are evenly distributed across the filter.

components.data: Using the ocular reticule, select an appropriate number of grid squares so that there are 10–100 stained viruses in each field.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Using the ocular reticule, select an appropriate number of grid squares so that there are 10–100 stained viruses in each field.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 43 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: Viruses can generally be distinguished from cells by their staining characteristics. Viruses appear as bright pinpricks of light, whereas cells generally have discernable size (see Fig. 1 in guidelines).
source_data.thread_text: Viruses can generally be distinguished from cells by their staining characteristics. Viruses appear as bright pinpricks of light, whereas cells generally have discernable size (see Fig. 1 in guidelines).
source_data.body: Viruses can generally be distinguished from cells by their staining characteristics. Viruses appear as bright pinpricks of light, whereas cells generally have discernable size (see Fig. 1 in guidelines).

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 43 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: If the 95% confidence intervals (see step 48) overlap for three transects of 20 random fields containing at least 200 viruses, it indicates that 20 fields is adequate to compensate for the variation in viral abundance among fields.
source_data.thread_text: If the 95% confidence intervals (see step 48) overlap for three transects of 20 random fields containing at least 200 viruses, it indicates that 20 fields is adequate to compensate for the variation in viral abundance among fields.
source_data.body: If the 95% confidence intervals (see step 48) overlap for three transects of 20 random fields containing at least 200 viruses, it indicates that 20 fields is adequate to compensate for the variation in viral abundance among fields.

components.data: Estimate the abundance of viruses by counting at least 20 random fields. Keep a tally of the number of particles in each field so that the variation in abundance of particles among fields can be determined.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Estimate the abundance of viruses by counting at least 20 random fields. Keep a tally of the number of particles in each field so that the variation in abundance of particles among fields can be determined.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 44 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: These data can be used to determine whether the distribution of particles across the filter is random. (The data should follow a Poisson distribution where the mean equals variance, although 20 fields should resemble a normal distribution.)
source_data.thread_text: These data can be used to determine whether the distribution of particles across the filter is random. (The data should follow a Poisson distribution where the mean equals variance, although 20 fields should resemble a normal distribution.)
source_data.body: These data can be used to determine whether the distribution of particles across the filter is random. (The data should follow a Poisson distribution where the mean equals variance, although 20 fields should resemble a normal distribution.)

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 44 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: Particles touching two edges of the grid (e.g., left side and top) should be counted, whereas particles touching the other two edges (e.g., right side and bottom) should not be counted.
source_data.thread_text: Particles touching two edges of the grid (e.g., left side and top) should be counted, whereas particles touching the other two edges (e.g., right side and bottom) should not be counted.
source_data.body: Particles touching two edges of the grid (e.g., left side and top) should be counted, whereas particles touching the other two edges (e.g., right side and bottom) should not be counted.

components.data: For each sample, record the number of particles counted in each field, the number of fields counted, the area of the field, and the volume of sample filtered.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: For each sample, record the number of particles counted in each field, the number of fields counted, the area of the field, and the volume of sample filtered.

components.data: The abundance of viruses mL<sup>–1</sup> (V<sub>t</sub>) in the sample = V<sub>c</sub> ÷ F<sub>c</sub> × A<sub>t</sub> ÷ A<sub>f</sub> ÷ S, where V<sub>c</sub> = total number of viruses counted, F<sub>c</sub> = total number of fields counted, A<sub>t</sub> = surface area of the filter (µm<sup>2</sup>) (see note below), A<sub>f</sub> = area of each field (µm<sup>2</sup>), and S = volume of sample filtered (mL).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The abundance of viruses mL<sup>–1</sup> (V<sub>t</sub>) in the sample = V<sub>c</sub> ÷ F<sub>c</sub> × A<sub>t</sub> ÷ A<sub>f</sub> ÷ S, where V<sub>c</sub> = total number of viruses counted, F<sub>c</sub> = total number of fields counted, A<sub>t</sub> = surface area of the filter (µm<sup>2</sup>) (see note below), A<sub>f</sub> = area of each field (µm<sup>2</sup>), and S = volume of sample filtered (mL).

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 46 of Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.protocol_name_html: Enumeration of virus particles in aquatic or sediment samples by epifluorescence microscopy
source_data.annotation: Note that for a 25- mm Anodisc filter, the diameter of the filter inside the plastic ring is 19 mm, which corresponds to an area of 283,528,737 µm<sup>2</sup>. If a filtration tower is used that has a diameter less than that of the surface of the filter, it will be necessary to correct for the smaller filtration surface area. This is most accurately done by using the microscope to determine the maximum width of the filter across which virus particles can be observed [Patel et al. 2007].
source_data.thread_text: Note that for a 25- mm Anodisc filter, the diameter of the filter inside the plastic ring is 19 mm, which corresponds to an area of 283,528,737 µm<sup>2</sup>. If a filtration tower is used that has a diameter less than that of the surface of the filter, it will be necessary to correct for the smaller filtration surface area. This is most accurately done by using the microscope to determine the maximum width of the filter across which virus particles can be observed [Patel et al. 2007].
source_data.body: Note that for a 25- mm Anodisc filter, the diameter of the filter inside the plastic ring is 19 mm, which corresponds to an area of 283,528,737 µm<sup>2</sup>. If a filtration tower is used that has a diameter less than that of the surface of the filter, it will be necessary to correct for the smaller filtration surface area. This is most accurately done by using the microscope to determine the maximum width of the filter across which virus particles can be observed [Patel et al. 2007].

components.data: The total number of particles counted will determine the size of the 95% confidence intervals on the estimates of viral abundance. By assuming a Poisson distribution, the 95% confidence intervals can be estimated using the following equations (Suttle 1993):
